title: Were some of rock hits of the 70's actually recorded by studio musicians rather than the actual band members? - Quora

response.answer_text: Read the book “The Wrecking Crew”. They recorded numerous hits for artists including The Beach Boys, Gary Lewis and the Playboys, The Byrds, The Mamas and the Papas, The Association, Bread, The Turtles, Sonny and Cher, Johnny Rivers, The Monkees, and many others. Here is a partial list from the 1970s, courtesy of Wikipedia: 1970 "(They Long to Be) Close to You" The Carpenters "Cracklin' Rosie" Neil Diamond "Arizona" Mark Lindsay "I Think I Love You" The Partridge Family "Bridge over Troubled Water" Simon & Garfunkel 1971 "Rainy Days and Mondays" The Carpenters "Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves" Cher "Sooner or Later" The Grass Roots "Don't Pull Your Love" Hamilton, Joe Frank & Reynolds "Indian Reservation" Raiders 1972 "Hurting Each Other" The Carpenters "(Last Night) I Didn't Get to Sleep at All" The 5th Dimension "It Never Rains in Southern California" Albert Hammond "Rockin' Pneumonia and the Boogie Woogie Flu" Johnny Rivers 1973 "Yesterday Once More" The Carpenters "Half-Breed" Cher "All I Know" Art Garfunkel "The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia" Vicki Lawrence 1974 "Chevy Van" Sammy Johns 1975 "Rhinestone Cowboy" Glen Campbell "Love Will Keep Us Together" Captain & Tennille 2015 "I'm Not Gonna Miss You" [123] Glen Campbell

You don’t have to limit to just the 70s. This has been true in popular music since the beginning of recording technology. What changed in the 60s is that the “band” became a recognized entity for the general public, whereas previously it was usually just a singer. That singer could be backed by any musicians, and very few listeners knew or cared who they might be. Buddy Holly had his Crickets, and Elvis had varying groups through his career, but the star was the star. When the Beatles and other groups became big things, record labels were still stuck in that older mindset, and usually wanted to think of bands as a star singer plus some backing musicians. They were wary of relying on untested players to get them hits, so they brought in musicians from their stable of studio regulars. The Beatles managed to avoid this, but many other bands did not. It was the record labels putting up the money, so often the bands didn’t have the clout to demand otherwise.
